skip.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to not do something that you usually do or that you should do
skip.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: She skipped lunch in order to go shopping.
Williams skipped the game to be with his wife in the hospital.
He skipped chemistry class three times last month.
skip.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to not read, mention, or deal with something that would normally come or happen next
skip.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: I decided to skip the first chapter.
Let’s skip to the last item on the agenda.
I suggest we skip over the details and get to the point.
skip.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to go from one subject to another in no fixed order
skip.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: It’s difficult to have a conversation with her because she skips from one topic to another.
skip.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to move forward with quick steps and jumps
skip.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: He turned and skipped away, singing happily to himself.
skip.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to jump over a rope as you swing it over your head and under your feet, as a game or for exercise
skip.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: if a ball or something similar skips off a surface, it quickly moves away from that surface after hitting it – used especially in news reports
skip.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: The ball skipped off Bond’s glove and bounced toward the fence.
skip.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: a large container for bricks, wood, and similar heavy waste
